item.title: Tesla Sues Ex-Optimus Engineer Alleging Theft of Robotic Trade Secrets
item.description: Tesla Inc. sued a former engineer with the company’s highly secretive Optimus program, accusing him of stealing confidential information about the humanoid robot and setting up a rival startup in Silicon Valley.
item.dc:creator: Dana Hull

media:content.media:description: A Tesla Inc. Optimus robot at the Paris Motor Show in Paris, on Oct. 15.

item.title: GameStop’s Future Is in Trading Cards, CEO Says
item.description: GameStop Corp., the largest standalone video-game retailer in the US, will focus on growing its trading card business, Chief Executive Officer Ryan Cohen said at the company’s annual shareholder meeting Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Cecilia D'Anastasio

media:content.media:description: Packs of Pokemon Co. cards in Random Lake, Wisconsin, U.S., on Thursday, July 1, 2021. In 2020 overall trading card sales climbed a record 142% on EBay, and Pokemon led the pack, averaging five card sales a minute—more than even baseball cards. This year, EBay listings of Pokemon cards were up 1,046% in the first quarter.

item.title: UK Pension Intervention Will Unlock Capital, Tech Minister Says
item.description: The London Stock Exchange is under-capitalized and the UK government’s plan to intervene in pension funds — forcing them to invest in private companies — will boost the amount of money being pumped into the economy, Technology Secretary Peter Kyle said.
item.dc:creator: Jillian Deutsch, Lizzy Burden

media:content.media:description: The London Stock Exchange Group Plc headquarters in Paternoster Square in the City of London, UK, on Thursday, Jan. 9, 2025. The pound dropped to a more than one-year low, stocks fell and gilts extended a fourth day of losses on concern the Labour government will struggle to keep the deficit in check as borrowing costs surge.

item.title: US Says Huawei’s 2025 Output No More Than 200,000 AI Chips
item.description: A senior Trump administration official projected that Huawei Technologies Co.’s output of its Ascend AI chip will be at or below 200,000 for 2025, responding to US lawmakers’ concerns that China is gaining ground in production of advanced semiconductors.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Lucey, Debby Wu

media:content.media:description: Shoppers line up outside a Huawei store in Beijing.

item.title: Arm CEO Sides With Nvidia on US Export Limits on China
item.description: Arm Holdings Plc CEO Rene Haas aligned himself with Nvidia Corp. Chief Executive Officer Jensen Huang in saying that US export controls on China threaten to slow overall technological advances and are ultimately bad for consumers and companies. Haas spoke Thursday in an interview with Bloomberg at the Founders Forum Global conference in Oxford.

item.title: Synthesia CEO Riparbelli on Tech Opportunities in Europe
item.description: Synthesia CEO Victor Riparbelli says ongoing political tension has created better opportunities for entrepreneurs to build companies as focus shifts away from regulation and into the technology and defense sectors. He speaks with Bloomberg's Tom Mackenzie at the Founders Forum in Oxfordshire. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Oracle Soars to Record After Seeing ‘Dramatically Higher’ Sales
item.description: Oracle Corp. shares soared to a record high after the software maker projected a 70% gain in cloud infrastructure sales this fiscal year, giving a bullish outlook for the closely watched business.
item.dc:creator: Brody Ford

media:content.media:description: The Oracle offices in Redwood City, California.

item.title: Why Voyager Shares Are Jumping After Upsized IPO
item.description: Voyager Technologies shares ended their debut trading day up 82% after the company raised $383 million in an upsized US initial public offering. Norah Mulinda reports on “Bloomberg Open Interest.”

item.title: Micron Pledges $200 Billion Investment in US Manufacturing
item.description: Chipmaker Micron Technology Inc. said it will spend about $200 billion on US manufacturing, research and development, the latest company to pledge large-scale investments in the country since President Donald Trump won election.
item.dc:creator: Dana Wollman

item.title: Micron to Invest About $200B in US Chip Manufacturing
item.description: Micron Technology said it will spend about $200 billion on US manufacturing, research and development. The spending will include roughly $150 billion for domestic manufacturing capacity and another $50 billion for R&D. Jake Silverman has more on “Bloomberg The Open.”

item.title: Mattel Taps OpenAI to Help It Design Toys, Other Products
item.description: The first release from the collaboration is expected later this year.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Buckley

media:content.media:description: Polly Pocket PollyWheels. Photographer: DANIEL ACKER

item.title: CoreWeave Shorts Face 150% Borrow Costs After $1.6 Billion Loss
item.description: CoreWeave Inc.’s soaring share price is torching short sellers who are paying high prices to bet that the stock will soon fall back to earth.
item.dc:creator: Carmen Reinicke

item.title: Yahoo Adds New AI Features to Mail App in Attempt to Up Usage
item.description: Yahoo is rolling out new artificial intelligence features for its email platform in an effort to better engage one of its fast-growing subset of users: Gen Z and millennials.
item.dc:creator: Samantha Kelly

media:content.media:description: The Yahoo Mail catch up screen. Source: Yahoo

item.title: Arm CEO Sides With Nvidia Against US Export Limits on China
item.description: Arm Holdings Plc Chief Executive Officer Rene Haas said Thursday that US export controls on China threaten to slow overall technological advances and are ultimately bad for consumers and companies, aligning himself with Nvidia Corp. Chief Executive Officer Jensen Huang and others looking to ease tensions between Washington and Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Jake Rudnitsky, Tom Mackenzie

media:content.media:description: Rene Haas, chief executive officer of Arm Holdings.

item.title: Sam Altman Says 2026 May Be a Big Year for AI
item.description: On this extended interview from The Circuit with Emily Chang, the OpenAI CEO explains how the Stargate project fits into the future of scientific discovery.
item.dc:creator: David Rovella

media:content.media:description: Sam Altman, left, lays out his vision of the future of artificial intelligence in an extended interview from The Circuit with Emily Chang.

item.title: Sequoia Leads $75 Million Deal for Industrial Software Startup
item.description: Nominal wants to make it easier for companies in defense, energy and manufacturing to develop new products.
item.dc:creator: Paayal Zaveri

media:content.media:description: Nominal co-founders from left, Jason Hoch, Cameron McCord and Bryce Strauss Source: Nominal/handout

item.title: Airbnb to Offer FIFA-Themed Experiences as World Cup Tournaments Fuel Travel Demand
item.description: Airbnb Inc. is partnering with FIFA to offer limited-time, celebrity-led activities for soccer fans, taking advantage of an uptick in travel demand in cities hosting World Cup tournaments.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Lung

media:content.media:description: The Airbnb logo on a smartphone arranged in the Brooklyn Borough of New York, US, on Thursday, May 4, 2023. Airbnb Inc. is scheduled to release earnings figures on May 9.

item.title: Bose Launches New QuietComfort Earbuds with Wireless Charging
item.description: Audio hardware brand Bose Corp. unveiled three new products, including noise-canceling earbuds and two different portable Bluetooth speakers.
item.dc:creator: Chris Welch

media:content.media:description: Bose’s second-generation QuietComfort Ultra Earbuds.

item.title: ChatGPT Should Reach Billions of Users, OpenAI’s Simo Says
item.description: OpenAI’s incoming head of applications, Fidji Simo, said she sees growing ChatGPT’s customer base to billions of users.
item.dc:creator: Benoit Berthelot

media:content.media:description: Fidji Simo

item.title: Salmon Farm Technology Firm Raises Targets on Investment Surge
item.description: As salmon farmers pour money into solving the problem of how to increase production while keeping control of lice in their pens, a Norwegian developer of aquaculture technologies is boosting its targets for the sale of everything from deepwater nets to AI-controlled feeding systems.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Treloar

media:content.media:description: Nets cover a salmon cage

item.title: Apple’s 10 Biggest Challenges, From AI to Tariffs
item.description: Apple Inc., long the envy of its Silicon Valley peers, is now facing one of the most trying times of the post-Steve Jobs era.
item.dc:creator: Mark Gurman

media:content.media:description: Tim Cook, chief executive officer of Apple.

item.title: African Backer of Tech Unicorns Eyes AI in Healthcare Deals
item.description: Chronos Capital, an early backer of emerging market unicorns Tyme Group and Optasia, is looking to invest in companies deploying artificial intelligence in healthcare as it seeks to capitalize on a technology that’s expected to transform the medical industry.
item.dc:creator: Prinesha Naidoo

media:content.media:description: AI signage.

item.title: Zuckerberg Snaps Back Into ‘Founder Mode’ on AI for Better or Worse
item.description: Welcome to Tech In Depth, our daily newsletter with reporting and analysis about the business of tech from Bloomberg’s journalists around the world. Today, Kurt Wagner assesses Mark Zuckerberg’s record when he goes into “founder mode.”
item.dc:creator: Kurt Wagner

media:content.media:description: Mark Zuckerberg, chief executive officer of Meta Platforms Inc., during the Meta Connect event in Menlo Park, California, US, on Wednesday, Sept. 25, 2024. Meta Platforms Inc. debuted its first pair of augmented reality glasses, devices that show a combined view of the digital and physical worlds, a key step in Chief Executive Officer Mark Zuckerberg’s goal of one day offering a hands-free alternative to the smartphone.

item.title: Meta Sues Hong Kong Firm in Crackdown on Deepfake Nude Apps
item.description: Meta Platforms Inc. is suing a Hong Kong-based business for allegedly promoting so-called nudify apps, as the Facebook owner attempts to combat a surge in naked and sexual images created by artificial intelligence.
item.dc:creator: Angus Whitley

media:content.media:description: This photo illustration created on July 18, 2023, in Washington, DC, shows an advertisement to create AI girls reflected in a public service announcement issued by the FBI regarding malicious actors manipulating photos and videos to create explicit content and sextortion schemes. Photo apps digitally undressing women, sexualized text-to-image prompts creating "AI girls" and manipulated images fuelling "sextortion" rackets -- a boom in deepfake porn is outpacing US and European efforts to regulate the technology. (Photo by Stefani REYNOLDS / AFP) (Photo by STEFANI REYNOLDS/AFP via Getty Images) Photographer: STEFANI REYNOLDS/AFP

item.title: Netflix Co-CEO Sees Warner Split as Part of Broader ‘Shakeout’
item.description: Warner Bros. Discovery Inc.’s decision to split into two independent companies is a sign of a broader “shakeout” across a media industry that has become increasingly dominated by streaming and on-demand services, Netflix Inc. co-Chief Executive Officer Greg Peters said.
item.dc:creator: Jake Rudnitsky

media:content.media:description: Greg Peters at the Founders Forum Global conference in Great Tew, UK, June 12.

item.title: Trump Plan to Kill Dozens of NASA Missions Threatens US Space Supremacy
item.description: The White House’s spending plans would further the space agency’s evolution toward becoming an incubator for private industry
item.dc:creator: Loren Grush

media:content.media:description: The Perseverance Mars rover, in this image provided by NASA, in 2024.

item.title: Tencent Said to Study Deal for $15 Billion Game Developer Nexon
item.description: Tencent Holdings Ltd. is studying a potential deal for Nexon Co., as the Chinese internet giant looks for ways to bolster its lucrative gaming operations, people with knowledge of the matter said.
item.dc:creator: Dong Cao, Haze Fan

item.title: Is London Losing Its Edge as a Global Tech Hub?
item.description: Major UK fintech firms like Revolut and Wise are shifting their focus—and listings—to the US.
item.dc:creator: Tala Ahmadi

media:content.media:description: Skyscrapers and commercial buildings, beyond Tower Bridge, in the City of London, UK, on Monday, June 2, 2025. At least 10% of the UK's wealthy non-dom population have left the country following tighter tax rules introduced by Prime Minister Keir Starmer’s Labour government, according to a new report authored by a former Treasury economist.

item.title: Chinese Mid-Cap Stocks to Thrive on AI Boom, Ox Capital Says
item.description: Chinese mid-cap stocks will be the next winners as companies take advantage of advancements in artificial intelligence, according to a fund manager at Ox Capital Management Pty Ltd.
item.dc:creator: Carmeli Argana, Abhishek Vishnoi

media:content.media:description: Photo by WANG Zhao / AFP/ Getty Images Photographer: WANG ZHAO/AFP

item.title: DayOne Gets $3.5 Billion Funding for Johor Data Centers
item.description: DayOne Data Centers Singapore Pte. secured 15 billion ringgit ($3.6 billion) of multicurrency financing to support its green data centers in Malaysia’s Johor state, according to a statement from Oversea-Chinese Banking Corporation Ltd.
item.dc:creator: Ram Anand

media:content.media:description: Data center.
